answers.answer: A patients clinical history (signs and symptoms) are the major factor in diagnosing RSD. There is no specific blood test or other diagnostic test for RSD. Some tests that may help in trying to diagnose RSD:  X-rays can show thinning of bones. Nuclear bone scans can show characteristic uptake patterns which help diagnose RSD. You can also have a sympathetic nervous system test which will check for any disturbances. A thermography test measures blood flow and skin temp in RSD-effected areas.

question: After a severe fall and shoulder  surgery the pain in my fingers and hands has become progressively worse. Burning constantly.I am a diabetic with excellent sugar control, and have never had this pain before my fall. I have no signs of diabetes in my feet or legs . I have been a type 2 diabetic for about 10 years . Is there any test that will determine the exact problem ?  Will a nerve biopsy determine if this is RSDS or diabetes?
title: RSDS or first sign of diabetes in hands
